overview: Hidetaka Miyazaki (宮崎 英高) is a Japanese game designer. He worked in the IT industry before joining FromSoftware in 2004, where he directed Demon's Souls (2009) and Dark Souls (2011).

Meghan Morgan Juinio is an American video game producer and studio executive with over 25 years of experience in AAA development and production leadership. She is best known for her decade of work at Santa Monica Studio, where she served as Co-Studio Head and Director of Product Development, overseeing titles such as God of War Ragnarök and God of War Ragnarök: Valhalla. Juinio joined Santa Monica Studio in 2015 as Senior Manager of Production, later advancing to Director of Production and then Co-Studio Head. In these roles, she guided cross-disciplinary teams, managed large-scale development pipelines, and helped define the creative and commercial direction of PlayStation’s flagship franchises. Her leadership emphasized operational excellence, sustainability, and fostering an inclusive studio culture. Prior to her tenure at Sony, Juinio held senior production roles at Nexon America, Activision, THQ, Konami Digital Entertainment, and Square USA, contributing to a wide range of titles including Spider-Man: Shattered Dimensions, True Crime: Hong Kong (later Sleeping Dogs), Call of Duty Online, SmackDown vs. Raw, and Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within. A long-time advocate for sustainable game development and industry inclusivity, Juinio currently serves on the Advisory Board of Women in Games International (WIGI) and as a Computer Simulation and Gaming Advisory Committee Member for Milwaukee Area Technical College. She frequently speaks on production strategy, leadership, and the future of large-scale game development, emphasizing the need for creativity, balance, and “fun first” design in an increasingly volatile industry.

Tetsuya Nomura (野村 哲也) was born October 8, 1970 in Kōchi, Japan. Before working for Square as character designer, he was at a vocational school creating art for advertisements. In 1992, Square hired him to work on the battle graphics of Final Fantasy V and then as graphic director in 1994 for Final Fantasy VI . In 1996, a game project called Silent Chaos (which was originally the sequel of Dark Earth ) was stopped after several months of development, and became a PlayStation game, developed in collaboration with Square. The characters, designed by François Rimasson at the beginning, were re-designed later by Tetsuya Nomura; but the project was never completed, and Silent Chaos was cancelled in November 1999, after two and a half years of development. Nomura's first major breakthrough came in 1997, when Square asked him to become character designer for Final Fantasy VII . In 1998, he worked on both Parasite Eve and Brave Fencer Musashi . The following year he impressed his superiors with his realistic character design in Final Fantasy VIII . He was given not only the job of character designer but also of battle visual director. Square then asked him to work on several other projects and decided to choose him to be character designer for their first game on PlayStation 2 ( The Bouncer ) and then for their first Final Fantasy installment on that console ( Final Fantasy X ). He continued working on Final Fantasy and Kingdom Hearts games.

Caryl Shaw is currently taking a break from making games to focus on her health and family. Most recently she was the Lead Producer for Creator Ecosystems for Fortnite at Epic Games. And prior to that she was the VP of Development for Double Fine Productions - working with the Psychonauts 2 team to ship that title during the pandemic, and as part of the management team facilitating the DF acquisition by Microsoft. Caryl has also worked for large developers like Electronic Arts/Maxis and Amazon as well as smaller companies like Telltale Games and ngmoco:). Her focus is typically on team management and growth, game production, online features, quality assurance management, and promoting diversity in the games industry. She's spoken internationally about a range of topics including: Running a Live Mobile Game, the changing role of Game Production in Development and Putting User-Generated Content to Work in Video Games. Her favorite spirit is Breaking and Entering Bourbon.

Neil Druckmann is a programmer, writer and creative director. Druckmann has worked for Naughty Dog since 2004.  He was initially hired as a programmer to work on the Jak and Daxter series.  He then became a game designer on Uncharted: Drake's Fortune. Druckmann also created  The Last of Us in collaboration with Bruce Straley.

Yoshio Sakamoto (坂本 賀勇), born July 23, 1959, is a Japanese video game designer from Nara. He graduated Osaka University of Arts and has been employed by Nintendo since 1982. His early work consisted primarily of script writing and scenario planning before moving on to the role of game director for Nintendo R&D1 's title Metroid - a series he has been creatively involved with ever since, either directing or supervising ( Metroid: Other M ). He would later form the Team Shikamaru group in the early 90’s within R&D1 to develop storylines for future titles developed by the team. In 2007, Sakamoto currently resides with the recently formed Nintendo SP&D (Special-Planning & Development) division which consists of members from the now defunct R&D1.
In 2008 Naoki Horii is CEO of development studio M2 .

Bruce Straley is a video game director, designer, and artist from America. His first job in the industry was in the art and design department of Western Technologies where he worked on 2 titles.  Following this, Straley worked at  Pacific Softscape. He then joined Crystal Dynamics where he met several other employees who were later to join Naughty Dog. At Naughty Dog, Straley was an artist on 1999's Crash Team Racing which was followed by several Jak and Daxter titles. He was a co-director of Uncharted: Drake's Fortune, then game director of Uncharted 2: Among Thieves. His subsequent projects were The Last of Us and Uncharted 4: A Thief's End.  He left Naughty Dog in September 2017 [1].

overview: After two years at the SCEE XDev studio in Liverpool, Ray was promoted to Producer in April 2011. He has worked on the Heavy Rain and the PS Move launch title The Shoot (PS3). Prior to this, Ray interned at the production department of Disney Interactive Studios for a year from mid-2006. Ray graduated with a first class degree from Brunel University, London, reading Multimedia Technology & Design with Professional Development, BSc (Hons).

Hideo Kojima was born on August 24, 1963 in Setagaya, Tokyo.
Kojima joined Konami in 1986 as a planner. In 1987, his first title Metal Gear was released. He and his title were well received, causing a big impact. He also directed Snatcher , Policenauts and released Metal Gear Solid in 1998, which sold over six million copies worldwide. This title made him famous internationally. In 2001, he directed Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty , the sequel to Metal Gear Solid . Newsweek chose him as the one of "10 most influential people to shape the future". He also served as the producer of Zone of the Enders . He is also known as a big movie fan, publicly commenting on and reviewing movies. Hideo Kojima became Vice President of Konami Computer Entertainment Japan, Inc. in 2011. He is currently CEO & CTO of Kojima Productions Co., Ltd. since 15 December 2015. Biography last updated: January 25, 2019 Awards The Game Awards 2016 – Industry Icon Award

overview: Shinji Mikami (三上 真司), born on 11 August 1965, is a Japanese game designer best known for his work on the Resident Evil series. After graduating from Doshisha University, Mikami was hired by Capcom in 1990 as a game planner. During his early years at the company he mostly worked on Disney-licensed titles, including Who Framed Roger Rabbit (1991), Aladdin (1993) and Goof Troop (1994). Mikami's next step was to create a game based on the earlier Capcom title Sweet Home . The idea was a horror-themed game where a team of special forces were trapped inside a mansion infested with zombies and other monsters. The game was called Biohazard , and was renamed Resident Evil upon its release in the United States. The game became an unexpected hit for Capcom, and a sequel was soon commissioned. Eventually Resident Evil grew into a successful franchise under the supervision of Shinji Mikami. Capcom then asked Mikami to create another survival horror series, which became known as Dino Crisis . Capcom then decided to establish Production Studio 4 as a means of keeping the survival horror team together, and appointed Shinji Mikami as the General Manager of the studio. With his new position, Mikami worked as executive producer on most Studio 4 titles including Dino Crisis 2 , Phoenix Wright and Devil May Cry (originally conceived as the fourth Resident Evil title). In 2001, Mikami made a controversial decision to make all future Studio 4 games exclusive to the Nintendo GameCube, despite it not being the leading format at the time. The first GameCube exclusive was a remake of the original Resident Evil which was to realize Mikami's true vision of the game, and well as a prequel Resident Evil Zero . Neither of these two games sold as well as Capcom had hoped, but Mikami decided to pursue his GameCube exclusivity, and announced five new games which he dubbed the "Capcom 5". Of the five GameCube exclusives, Mikami was to direct one title himself ( P.N.03 ) and act as producer on the remaining four titles ( Viewtiful Joe , Dead Phoenix, killer7 and Resident Evil 4 ). P.N.03 and Viewtiful Joe were the first of the Capcom 5 released. The Mikami-directed P.N.03 was a critical and commercial failure, while Viewtiful Joe gained praise but still failed to reach sales targets. Capcom's disappointment with the Capcom 5 grew more evident, as Dead Phoenix was cancelled and Viewtiful Joe was ported to the PlayStation 2, breaking Mikami's exclusivity agreement with Nintendo. Mikami voluntarily stepped down as General Manager of Production Studio 4 but still remained a member of the team. With the failure of P.N.03 now behind him, Mikami decided to concentrate on the creative aspects of the remaining Capcom 5 titles and took over directorial duties on Resident Evil 4. Under his direction, the Resident Evil series went through an evolution of changes. Resident Evil 4 was then released to critical acclaim and became a big selling title on the GameCube. As with Viewtiful Joe, Resident Evil 4 was later ported to the PlayStation 2 but Mikami refused to be involved in the conversion. That same year, Mikami co-wrote the story for the final Capcom 5 game killer7, which received mixed reviews. Shortly after the success of Resident Evil 4, Shinji Mikami departed from Capcom Production Studio 4 and joined many of his former colleagues at Clover Studio. Originally founded in 2004, Clover Studio was established by Capcom with the aim of creating new, original and innovative IPs, and its development staff was largely made up of former Resident Evil and Devil May Cry members. While working at Clover, Mikami supervised the development of an old-school style beat 'em up called God Hand. In 2006 Clover Studio was dissolved by Capcom following disappointing sales of its games Okami and God Hand, and Mikami resigned from Capcom along with many other Clover Studio staff. Soon after Clover's closure, Shinji Mikami, along with Atsushi Inaba (Clover Studio founder) and Hideki Kamiya (Devil May Cry creator) formed a new development studio called Seeds Inc. The company then changed its name to Platinum Games in a merger with ODD corporation. In 2009, Shinji Mikami worked at Platinum Games to direct Bayonetta . In March 2010, it was revealed he established a new development studio called Tango Gameworks . He worked as the executive producer until 2023.

overview: Shigeo Komori (小森 成雄) is a Japanese video game director, producer, writer, and lyricist. He has been working at Atlus at least since 2009. He has contributed to several games in the Megami Tensei / Megaten universe, but he is best known as the Director and the Producer of the Etrian Odyssey series of games.

Kurt Margenau used to make his own Flash games and interned at EA Tiburon before graduating from Georgia Tech in 2007. He then joined Red Fly Studio as a gameplay scripter. Since 2008, he has been with Naughty Dog as a Game Designer.

overview: Sami Järvi works at Remedy Entertainment and is best known for his role as Max Payne in the game of the same name for which he also wrote the story and screenplay. He can be seen in the graphic novel sequences of the game that act as cutscenes and his photograph was also used for the texture of the main character.

Tristan Lefranc joined The Creative Assembly Ltd. as an Associate Producer in 2007. He has previously held marketing positions at Nintendo France and Ubisoft to consolidate his degree in Software Production obtained in Paris (2003). He went back to development as part of the team developing Tom Clancy's Ghost Recon 2 and discovered he has an addiction in the search of production pipeline best practices; while shaping his skills on multiple development sites projects. With a nomad soul, he worked in France and China, prior to joining SEGA’s development team in England.

Angie Smets is VP, Head of Development Strategy at PlayStation Studios since April 2023. Previously, she was the Studio Director and an Executive Producer at Guerrilla B.V. She was with the company since its early days as Lost Boys starting in 1999.

overview: Hitoshi Sakimoto (b. 26th February 1969) is a composer and a producer. He started making games in 1987 with friends and commenced freelance work in 1989. In 1998 he was hired to work at Square Co., Ltd. and he left the company two years later. In October 2002 he founded his own studio: Basiscape Co., Ltd.

overview: Shuntaro Furukawa began his career at Nintendo in 1994 working in global marketing and accountancy. He later became a director of The Pokemon Company and, in 2015, was promoted to General Manager of the Corporate Planning Division. He joined the Nintendo Board of Directors in June 2016 and, on June 28th 2018, became the 6th president of Nintendo, succeeding Tatsumi Kimishima .

overview: Aaron has been in the game industry since 2009, starting with his studies at Georgia Tech. He worked on the Call of Duty franchise for several years at Raven Software , and, as of August 2021, works at Insomniac Games .
Roman Ribaric is a Founder and CEO of Croteam, a Development Studio based in Zagreb, Croatia.
Marty Stratton has been Executive Producer at id Software since December 2006. Previously, he had been Director of Business Development at the same company since 2000.

Todd Howard has been with Bethesda Softworks LLC since the early days, going back as far as the mid-nineties. Howard has produced and designed several of the company's releases including The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion, Fallout 3 , The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim and Fallout 4. In 2012 Howard was awarded the title of Best Game Director by the Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences.

overview: Game Designer·  Responsible, from January ’99 for the Rayman Game Boy Color design, level design and main character and enemy behaviour: a platform game which reached the highest quality standard for the GBC format. The project was created from scratch in Milan, including Engine and Tool development. The game shipped in March 2000, remaining in the top 20 of UK best selling GBC titles for about 90 weeks. The total sell-out since the release is above 680.000 units. Lead Game Designer· Responsible, from November ’99 for Walt Disney’s The Jungle Book: Mowgli’s Wild Adventure, for Game Boy Color design, level design and main character and enemy behaviour. The game shipped in November 2000, receiving excellent evaluations from the press and being recommended by Nintendo in its own buyer guide. The total sell-out since the release is above 378.000 units. Studio Manager Game Design· Responsible, from April 2000, for the Rayman M project, for both PS2 and PC. This is a multiplayer game, developed as an Italian-French co-production, with a team involving more than 50 persons between the two countries. The PS2 version shipped on November the 29th 2001. Studio Manager Game Design  ·   Responsible, from January 2002, for the “The Mummy” GBA project, for design and level design and studio managment. This is an action adventures game, developed as an Italian production, with a team involving less than 10 persons. Studio Manager Game Design  ·   Responsible, from February 2002, for “Tomb Raider the Prophecy” GBA project, for level design, game design and game design managment. This is an action game based on the famous brand, developed as an Italian production, with a team involving less than 12 persons. ·   Responsible of One new 3D multiplatform project based on a Tom Clancy license.

Jari Hokkanen's first footstep in the industry was at Supercell where he began his path to glory by working in games like Clash of Clans , Battle Buddies and Gunshine.net. In 2012 he joined Remedy Entertainment where he worked on Remedy's first iOS title Agents of Storm . After two years, Jari moved on to co-found Ministry of Games in order to apply his efforts to the challenge of starting a game development company. After a year of hardcore start-up life Jari moved to the Housemarque as a Level Designer working on games such as Alienation for PS4.

overview: Connie Booth is Group General Manager, Action RPG at Electronic Arts . This was first reported in March 2024. At the company she runs the portfolio that includes Motive Studios , Cliffhanger and BioWare . She reports directly to EA Entertainment head Laura Miele . Previously Booth was Senior Vice President, Head of Internal Production at PlayStation until October 2023. She had been with Sony for almost 30 years. She started in 1995 as a producer working with Naughty Dog to launch Crash Bandicoot (1996), but had already been with Sony Corporation of America since 1989. She worked on many PlayStation franchises, including Jak & Daxter , Sly Cooper , Ratchet & Clank , inFAMOUS , Resistance , Uncharted , The Last of Us and Marvel Spider-Man . No official statement was given when she left Sony. Booth is a member of the Academy of Interactive Arts & Science Hall of Fame.

overview: Larry Kuperman joined Stardock Corporation in 2001 as part of the sales and marketing team. He has been involved in the publication and distribution of numerous titles including The Corporate Machine, LightWeight Ninja, Galactic Civilizations I and II and others. Larry has worked with every major publisher and distributor including Activision, EA, Bethesda, THQ, Ubisoft as well as hundreds of independent game developers. In May of 2011, Larry left Stardock to accept a position as Business Development Manager at GameStop. In May of 2013, Larry joined Nightdive Studios as the Director of Business Development. Larry is a graduate of New York University and was awarded his MBA at the University of Detroit.

overview: Veteran game industry programmer. After starting out at Nippon Ichi and then moving on to tri-Ace. Yuichiro Kitao left tri-Ace in 2013 and started his own game studio, Gemdrops, where he now serves as its Director and CEO.

overview: Shigeo Komori (小森 成雄) is a Japanese video game director, producer, writer, and lyricist. He has been working at Atlus at least since 2009. He has contributed to several games in the Megami Tensei / Megaten universe, but he is best known as the Director and the Producer of the Etrian Odyssey series of games.

Kōtarō Uchikoshi (打越鋼太郎, born Nov. 17, 1973), also known by the pen name Hagane Tsukishio (槻潮鋼) is a scenario writer from Higashimurayama, Tokyo, Japan. He worked as a writer on several visual novels for KID from 1999 to 2004, including the first two Memories Off games and the Infinity series. In 2004, he left KID and joined Chunsoft at the invitation of Jirō Ishii .

overview: Tetsuya Nomura (野村 哲也) was born October 8, 1970 in Kōchi, Japan. Before working for Square as character designer, he was at a vocational school creating art for advertisements. In 1992, Square hired him to work on the battle graphics of Final Fantasy V and then as graphic director in 1994 for Final Fantasy VI . In 1996, a game project called Silent Chaos (which was originally the sequel of Dark Earth ) was stopped after several months of development, and became a PlayStation game, developed in collaboration with Square. The characters, designed by François Rimasson at the beginning, were re-designed later by Tetsuya Nomura; but the project was never completed, and Silent Chaos was cancelled in November 1999, after two and a half years of development. Nomura's first major breakthrough came in 1997, when Square asked him to become character designer for Final Fantasy VII . In 1998, he worked on both Parasite Eve and Brave Fencer Musashi . The following year he impressed his superiors with his realistic character design in Final Fantasy VIII . He was given not only the job of character designer but also of battle visual director. Square then asked him to work on several other projects and decided to choose him to be character designer for their first game on PlayStation 2 ( The Bouncer ) and then for their first Final Fantasy installment on that console ( Final Fantasy X ). He continued working on Final Fantasy and Kingdom Hearts games.

Johan Andersson has been with Paradox Interactive since the start in 1999, and worked as game designer and lead programmer for the Europa Universalis series, as well as the original Hearts of Iron game. Since 2002 Johan has been the Director of Development of Paradox's internally developed titles completing titles such as Crusader Kings , Victoria: An Empire Under the Sun , and Hearts of Iron II . Formerly an employee of Funcom Oslo A/S , where he was responsible for titles such as Nightmare Circus and NBA Hang Time , Andersson moved back to his native Stockholm to work as a senior programmer for Target Games in January 1998. He was involved from the start in developing the award winning Europa engine, which has been used for over half a dozen successful games the last decade.

overview: Joe Shely is a game designer specializing in combat mechanics. He started at Edge of Reality in 2002, shipping three titles for Xbox, PS2 and Gamecube. In 2005, he took a job with Blizzard Entertainment . There he shipped four expansions for World of Warcraft and worked on Diablo III: Reaper of Souls.

Larry Kuperman joined Stardock Corporation in 2001 as part of the sales and marketing team. He has been involved in the publication and distribution of numerous titles including The Corporate Machine, LightWeight Ninja, Galactic Civilizations I and II and others. Larry has worked with every major publisher and distributor including Activision, EA, Bethesda, THQ, Ubisoft as well as hundreds of independent game developers. In May of 2011, Larry left Stardock to accept a position as Business Development Manager at GameStop. In May of 2013, Larry joined Nightdive Studios as the Director of Business Development. Larry is a graduate of New York University and was awarded his MBA at the University of Detroit.

overview: In 2008 Dave Clark is Vice President, New Business Development at Eidos . He has been in marketing for a long time at the company and previously at SCi Games Ltd. before it was acquired by Eidos.
In 2008 Naoki Horii is CEO of development studio M2 .

Since 1st October 2007 Larry Sparks is Vice President of Marketing at Square Enix Ltd. . Most recently he served as Global Head of Brands Management at Eidos Interactive Ltd. and led the launch of brands including Hitman: Blood Money and Just Cause . He is also widely respected in the industry for his key role in the early and most recent Tomb Raider series , one of the world’s most successful franchises selling over 32 million copies worldwide.
Eric was one of the founding members of legendary computer game team " The Bitmap Brothers " along with Steve Kelly and Mike Montgomery in 1987.

Zhenghua Yang (Z) is the founder, executive producer, narrative director, designer, audio engineer, & artist of Serenity Forge , a value-driven video game development company in Boulder, Colorado. Z was born in China and immigrated to the U.S. at the age of 10. Having built his first computer at the age of 6 and programmed his first video game at the age of 10, Z started Serenity Forge after a near-fatal illness at the age of 18, focusing on creating meaningful & artistic games that challenge the way we think. Since then, Z worked to develop games including Where the Water Tastes Like Wine , Once Upon a Coma , Half Past Fate , The King’s Bird , and published games such as Lifeless Planet , A Case of Distrust , Pinstripe , and Four Sided Fantasy . In Addition, Z works with hospitals in creating interactive experiences for children with severe illnesses to give them a sense of freedom during their hospitalization. Z is a TEDx speaker and holds many awards in business and design; his art and games have reached fans around the world and have been exhibited at museums such as the Smithsonian Institution & Denver Botanic Gardens.
Akihiro Hino is the CEO and President of Level-5 Inc. , which he founded in 1998. Before that, he worked at Riverhill Software Inc. working on the OverBlood series for the original PlayStation.

overview: Takashi Tezuka (手塚 卓志, also known as Ten Ten ) was born November 17, 1960 in Osaka, Japan. A graduate of the Design Department of Osaka University of Arts, he joined Nintendo in April 1984. Tezuka took leading roles in designing some of the company's best-known titles, including installments in Mario and Zelda series. Together with Shigeru Miyamoto , he is currently the general manager of the development department in Nintendo EAD .

After a brief spell in the depths of QA, Dan Croucher began his career in the games industry in earnest designing and producing interactive TV games at Babel Media . Following a move to localisation QA project management at Babel, Dan then moved to Relentless Software in 2005, starting as assistant producer on Buzz!: The Big Quiz and Buzz!: The Mega Quiz . Dan continues to make Buzz! games at Relentless, most recently completing the move to PS3 with Buzz!: Quiz TV and helping introduce user-generated content to the video game quizzing with the MyBuzz! website.

Often called the "Father of Computer Gaming", Sid Meier has been honored with virtually every major award in the gaming industry and in 1999, was the second person ever to be inducted into the Academy of Interactive Arts and Science's "Hall of Fame." His career in the industry started in 1982, when he founded MicroProse together with Bill Stealey . The first game he wrote for the company was Chopper Rescue . After initially working on combat flight simulator and military strategy games, he achieved his real fame with his Civilization game (1991). Before the release of the game, he had already been bought out of the company by Stealey, and Meier had become a private contractor, working seemingly exclusively for the company. He received money up front, more when the game delivered and royalties on each sold copy. The Vice President that replaced Meier at the company did not receive any bonuses on the Meier titles sold and therefore gave them low priority at the company. In 1996, he left MicroProse to join the newly-founded Firaxis Games by Jeff Briggs . In 1997, the company’s first release was Sid Meier's Gettysburg! , followed by Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri in 1999, which was enhanced later in the year with Sid Meier's Alien Crossfire . Firaxis then released two more games, Sid Meier's Civilization III and Sid Meier's SimGolf . In 2004 and 2005, his original Pirates! game was remade as Sid Meier's Pirates! and the Civilization series was continued with Civilization IV .

overview: Jacob Solomon graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a Bachelor's of Science in Computer Science in 2000, and is currently (2002) studying for his Masters from the Johns Hopkins University. Since receiving his bachelor's, he has worked as a programmer (Tools Manager) at Firaxis on both Civilization III and SimGolf. An avid gamer since the earliest days of PC gaming, Jacob is flooded with horror when he realizes that he was actually leaning towards corporate consulting as a possible career path before his extremely fortunate, extremely fortuitous discovery of his current position at Firaxis. (Source: Firaxis web site)

overview: In July 2007 Karim Farghaly became head of Strategy First's new North American Sales Division. He oversees all sales activities for both Empire Interactive and Strategy First in the U.S., Canada and Latin America. Previously he was employed at Aspyr Media since April 2005, where he was responsible for Aspyr's, North American retail sales. Prior to Aspyr, Karim was European Sales Director for the OEM division of Interplay Entertainment Corp. in London.

Tim Campbell has been working in the videogame industry since 1996 and has helped deliver several million-selling titles for the PC. At the turn of the millennium, Campbell worked for EA Paciifc , working on hit titles including Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 and Nox . He then served as a Senior and Lead Designer at Blizzard Entertainment . In his time at Blizzard, Campbell shipped both WarCraft III: Reign of Chaos and WarCraft III: The Frozen Throne , while also contributing to StarCraft: Ghost (ultimately cancelled) and World of WarCraft in supporting roles. He was the co-founder and president of SuperVillain Studios in the mid-2000s, and FireForge from 2011 to 2016. He was the game director of inXile Entertainment's Wasteland 3 (2020). In October 2020, he co-founded Frost Giant Studios with Tim Morten , another former EA and Blizzard developer, to work on Stormgate . He has also written published material for the popular print-based Dungeons & Dragons and WarCraft role-playing games. Known Aliases : "el Presidente", "Biodoug", "Commander Og"

overview: Tetsuya Mizuguchi was born in Sapporo, Japan in 1965. He was educated at Nihon University's Faculty of Arts and joined Sega in 1990. His first work was Megalopolice, a Japanese motion ride with computer graphics. He then turned his attention to racing simulations, and in 1995 created the arcade game Sega Rally Championship . Mizuguchi is also known for his work on Manx TT , Rez, and Space Channel 5 , among other best selling titles. In 1996, Mizuguchi left Sega's AM3 division to form AM Annex , where he and his team created Sega Touring Car Championship and Sega Rally Championship. On April 9, 2000, Sega's amusement division "AM9" became United Game Artists (UGA) . Mizuguchi was President and Chief Operating Officer of the studio. They produced Space Channel 5 and Rez, which were praised among gaming communities as fresh and innovative titles. On October 7, 2003, Mizuguchi was a guest on "Tokyo Game Lounge", a webcast radio program produced in Tokyo. During the webcast, he announced his retirement from Sega. An article by Hirohiko Niizumi/Tor Thorsen for GameSpot claims that the restructuring prompted Mizuguchi to leave the company. He explained of departure from Sega as follows: "Games are a very unique medium. They exist beyond language, beyond culture, and people are fascinated by games. I don't know how long I will live, but I want to learn more about games -- and there is more to learn about creating better games." After leaving Sega, Mizuguchi co-founded Q Entertainment with other former Sega employees. He left the company in 2014 when he founded Enhance, Inc. He is, as of May 2021, both the CEO and the sole employee of the company.

overview: After getting his Associates Degree in Graphic Arts, Tim started out in the QA department at Westwood Studios . He was quickly recognized for his attention to detail and was promoted to the role of Asset Manager. During his time as the company’s Asset Manager, he was asked to take on a dual role as the cinematic Video Compression Artist. He was tasked with the frame by frame analysis of all pre-rendered movies, correcting any errors, and putting them together into Westwood’s proprietary movie format. His role grew from correcting and consolidating artwork to creating it. He provided 3D artwork for the Playstation™ version of Dune: 2000™, and for Pirates: The Legend of Black Kat™ for the XBox™ and Playstation 2™. From there he was promoted to Associate Producer for the Emperor: Battle for Dune™ and Earth and Beyond™ projects. After the close of Westwood Studios, he joined his former Westwood colleagues at Petroglyph Games, Inc. as an Associate Producer, and then became Producer for Universe at War™ for the Xbox 360™. He later left Petroglyph to join Terminal Reality, Inc. as the Project Manager for Ghostbusters: The Video Game™ and Kinect Star Wars™. In March of 2012 he left Terminal Reality, Inc. to join Microsoft Studios as a Senior Producer. His previous game credits include the award winning Command & Conquer™ series, the Lands of Lore™ series, the Legend of Kyrandia™ series, the Dune™ RTS games, Blade Runner™, Pirates: The Legend of Black Kat™, Star Wars: Empire at War - Forces of Corruption™, Ghostbusters: The Video Game™, and most recently Kinect Star Wars™.
Valerie Arem specializes in interactive, animation, and commercial voice over services. In 2009, she works with Keith Arem 's company, PCB Productions .
In 2008 Naoki Horii is CEO of development studio M2 .

overview: Where Hirokazu Yasuhara left off, Takashi Iizuka picked up. He worked directly under Yasuhara in the design of Sonic 3 , and has since taken the reigns of the series. Sonic Adventure , the 3D rebirth of the little blue hedgehog that started it all, was the product of Iizuka's idea for a Sonic RPG. After the successful completion of that project, Iizuka headed to the US to head Sonic Team USA . Over in San Francisco, he was director, lead game designer and a level designer for Sonic Adventure 2 , Sonic Heroes , and Shadow the Hedgehog . He and his team developed the Wii game NiGHTS: Journey of Dreams . Due to Yuji Naka's departure from Sonic Team, he has taken the additional role of producer for the game.
Hideaki Itsuno has been working for Capcom at least since 1995. He was the Chief Director on Devil May Cry 4 and Dragon's Dogma.
Tadeusz Zuber is Quality Assurance Manager for Reality Pump in 2011. He started working for the company in April 2003.

Hyung-tae Kim (Hangul: 김형태, Hanja: 金亨泰), born in February 1978 in Seoul, is a Korean artist. He is best known for his work as illustrator and graphic designer for various role-playing games produced by Softmax .

From the early days growing up in Park Ridge NJ, Richard Lico has always been an avid console gamer. He's learning the finer points of Street Fighter to complete his Shaolin Scheming for world domination. Discovering the magic of 2-D/3-D animation as a published illustrator at the Savannah College of Art and Design, he forged his animation career. After obtaining a BFA in computer animation, he began work with Turner Broadcasting. He did graphic design and animation work for local advertising on animated billboards and TV, animated graphics for the 2000 MLB All-Star Game, and the opening for a CNN International show, "Sights & Sounds". Richard eventually left Turner to pursue his gaming passion. He found work as the lead animator with Sunstorm Interactive. During his time there, he worked on 5 published titles, including the popular Duke Nukem: Manhattan Project. He now hones his 3-D animation, and Street Fighter styling daily with the great people at Raven. Vive la Hadoken! Source: Selected articles from Raven Software Official Website - Company - Art http://www.ravensoft.com/frameset.html

overview: Johan Pilestedt serves as the CEO and Chief Creative of Arrowhead Game Studios since April 2009. Arrowhead is especially known for Helldivers II (2024). His responsibilities as CEO include setting the company's direction in alignment with the board's vision, signing projects, managing budgets, and overseeing both internal and external communications. Additionally, as the Game Director, he focuses on brand development for new and existing intellectual properties (IPs), ensuring projects maintain the highest standards of quality in design, and aligning them with the company's profile and sales potential. Prior to his role as CEO, Pilestedt served as a Producer and Lead Designer at Arrowhead, where he led the project team responsible for creating Magicka (2011), which won Game of the Year at SGA 2008. Pilestedt's educational background includes studies at Luleå University of Technology from 2004 to 2010.
Jason Orbaum (born March 1968) is a Director of NotGames .
